properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event will continue into Saturday. A hot and humid airmass is expected to remain in place into Saturday. Overnight minimum temperatures will remain near 20 degrees providing little relief. On Saturday temperatures will remain near thirty with humidex values in the upper thirties; however with the passage of a cold front, cooler temperatures and lower humidity is expected for the remainder of the weekend. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T19:19:20-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Local heavy downpours tonight. Scattered thunderstorms are expected to continue to develop and move slowly eastward across portions of the regions tonight. Local rainfall amounts of up to 50 millimetres may occur. These downpours are very localized and some places will see no rain at all. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Possible high levels of air pollution due to smoke from forest fires will continue tonight and tomorrow. Smoke plumes are moving over the region from several forest fires located in the Sandy Lake - Pikangikum region. Winds from the northwest have resulted in the smoke plumes affecting areas to the south and southeast of these fires. Air quality may deteriorate if the smoke descends to ground level. These smoke plumes will continue to affect the region into Saturday. If you, or someone in your care, develop symptoms, reduce or reschedule strenuous outdoors activities where ever possible until the air quality improves. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-07-06T16:31:46-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A very warm air mass will remain over New Brunswick tonight and much of Saturday but will be displaced from northwest to southeast during the day as a passing cold front will cause temperature and humidity levels to decrease. Minimum temperatures tonight will drop only to near 20 degrees. Temperatures will again climb to near 30 degrees or higher across most of the province on Saturday, with humidex values reaching 36 or higher before the passage of the cold front. Temperatures will remain cooler for coastal communities along the Bay of Fundy due to onshore breezes. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T17:23:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-06T01:24:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4245688377.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A very warm air mass will remain over Nova Scotia tonight and Saturday but will finally be displaced Saturday evening as a passing cold front will cause temperature and humidity levels to decrease rapidly. Overnight lows tonight are expected to drop only to 19 degrees. Temperatures will climb back to near 30 degrees by early Saturday afternoon, with humidex values in the mid to upper 30's over most of the mainland. Temperatures will remain cooler for coastal communities due to onshore breezes. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T17:25:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-06T01:26:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3218852194.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High heat and humidity continues tonight into Saturday. A relatively hot and humid airmass will remain in place into Saturday. Tonight minimum temperatures will remain near 20 degrees providing little relief. On Saturday temperatures are expected to be in the upper twenties with humidex values in the mid thirties. For areas closer to Georgian Bay and Lake Huron, temperatures will be a few degrees cooler. With the passage of a cold front on Saturday, cooler temperatures and lower humidity is expected for the remainder of the weekend. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T11:10:04-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms this evening. These thunderstorms may be capable of producing strong wind gusts up to 90 km/h, nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-07-06T11:21:47-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Thunderstorms clusters along a line from west to east will continue through Uxbridge over the next hour. Rainfall in excess of 50 millimetres in an hour is expected. A few locations may receive rainfall totals near 80 millimetres this evening. There is also hail to 2 cm in diameter possible. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy rainfall in combination with other weather factors, such as hail, wind and lightning will make outdoor activities unsafe. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of funnel clouds today. A trough of low pressure has lead to scattered thunderstorm development over southeastern Alberta and southwestern Saskatchewan this afternoon and evening. These thunderstorms will have the potential to produce a few cold core funnel clouds, a few of which have been reported in the Shaunavon region. The threat for funnel clouds will dissipate this evening as thunderstorms weaken with the loss of daytime heating. ### These types of funnel clouds are generated by weak rotation under rapidly growing clouds or weak thunderstorms. This weak rotation is normally not a danger near the ground. However, there is a chance that this rotation could intensify and become a weak landspout tornado. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T05:29:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-06T01:38:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0590170383.2019

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of funnel clouds today. A trough of low pressure has lead to scattered thunderstorm development over southeastern Alberta this afternoon and evening. These thunderstorms will have the potential to produce a few cold core funnel clouds, a few of which have been reported in the Shaunavon region in southwestern Saskatchewan. The threat for funnel clouds will dissipate this evening as thunderstorms weaken with the loss of daytime heating. ### These types of funnel clouds are generated by weak rotation under rapidly growing clouds or weak thunderstorms. This weak rotation is normally not a danger near the ground. However, there is a chance that this rotation could intensify and become a weak landspout tornado. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Thunderstorms with torrential downpours will continue to move slowly eastward and southeastward through portions of the regions over the next couple of hours. Radar estimates that some places have seen amounts over 50 mm. A few locations may receive rainfall totals near 80 millimetres. Frequent lightning is also associated. The storms are expected to weaken later this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy rainfall in combination with other weather factors, such as hail, wind and lightning will make outdoor activities unsafe. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-06T07:24:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-06T01:35:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2083401775.2019
